Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Okay, the user wants me to generate 20 open-ended questions about a complex global smartphone supply chain process. Theyve provided a detailed natural language description of the entire flow from RD to consumer delivery, with emphasis on multinational aspects, supplier coordination, logistics, and digital systems.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Hmm, this is quite comprehensive. The user seems to be either a supply chain professional looking for deeper analysis points, or perhaps an educator designing case study questions. The emphasis on thought-provoking and discovering insights suggests they want questions that uncover hidden complexities rather than basic facts.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Let me mentally walk through the supply chain stages they described: RD component sourcing TaiwanJapanSK etc. assembly in Malaysia global distribution airship regional DCs retail ecommerce post-sale support

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Key pain points I should probe: Geopolitical risks Taiwan microprocessors, USChina tensions Lead time mismatches between suppliers Sustainability pressures carbon footprint mention Digital system integration challenges Quality control across multiple tiers Demand forecasting accuracy for different regions

Name: Validation - PE
Text: checks their do not provide SQL instruction again Good, Ill avoid any technical query suggestions. Must keep all questions open-ended no yesno or factual questions.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: starts brainstorming angles For supplier risks: How would a sudden Taiwan fabrication plant shutdown cascade through the supply chain? For sustainability: What trade-offs might arise when optimizing for carbon footprint vs. cost in shipping methods?

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: notices their mention of just-in-time for high-demand markets thats a goldmine for questions Could ask about the fragility of JIT during disruptions like pandemics.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: spots their multiple currenciestime zones point Should include questions about financial hedging and real-time inventory visibility across time zones.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: double-checks they want 20 exactly Better count as I draft. Must avoid repetition each question should target a distinct aspect.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: thinks about their continuous improvement mention Will include a question about measuring success of such initiatives beyond just cost reduction.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: considers the warrantyrecall angle Thats often overlooked should ask about how recall processes differ across regions with varying regulations.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: verifies all questions avoid being answerable with yesno Example: Instead of Do they use AI for forecasting? How might predictive analytics improve their demand planning for emerging markets?

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: reviews for depth The best questions should make someone pause and say Hmm, I never thought about that before. Like the one about how sensor suppliers from Germany might affect quality control in Malaysia assembly.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: checks balance Got questions on tech digital systems, human factors labor compliance, environment carbon, finance currencies, and risk management. Good spread.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: final check All 20 questions are: Open-ended Based strictly on their description No SQLtechnical jargon Covering all critical phases they mentioned

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: notices they included VIPpre-order direct to consumers must include a question about that niche channels impact on the main supply chain
